EVENT.description: Any concept describing something changing in time.

OBJECT.description: Any reference to a class of objects.

EXPERIENCEABLE OBJECT.description: Any reference to a class of experienceable objects.

ABSOLUTE TIME REFERENCES.description: A time in the future or past defined without reference to the speaker time.

RELATIVE TIME REFERENCE.description: A time in the future or past defined by reference to the speaker time.

EVENT TENSE.description: The general position in time at which an event occurs, relative to the real or imaginary speakers time.

PAST EVENT.description: Before the real or imaginary speaker time.

WHENEVER IN THE PAST.description: Whenever in the past of the real of imaginary speaker.

JUST A MOMENT AGO.description: A few minutes/hours in the past of the speaker.

A SHORT WHILE AGO.description: A few hours/days in the past of the speaker.

SOME TIME AGO.description: Some days/weeks in the past of the speaker.

A LONG TIME AGO.description: Some months/years in the past of the speaker.

A VERY LONG TIME AGO.description: Many years in the past of the speaker.

FUTURE EVENT.description: After the real or imaginary speaker time.

WHENEVER IN THE SPEAKER FUTURE.description: Any time in the future of the real or imaginary speaker.

SHORTLY AFTER NOW.description: A short duration after the speaker time.

ASPECT.description: The way an event is viewed in relation to the flow of time.

PERFECTIVE.description: An event that has been completed.

DEICTIC.description: A pointer relative to the real or imaginary speaker.

OBJECT DEICTIC.description: A relative pointer to an object.

PP1SG.description: A relative pointer to the speaker.

PP2SG.description: A relative pointer to the addressee.

PP2INCDU.description: A relative pointer to the speaker and the addressee.

PP2EXCDU.description: A relative pointer to the speaker and someone else but not the addressee.

PP2DU.description: A relative pointer to the addressee and someone else but not the speaker.

PP2TRI.description: A relative pointer to the addressee and two other people but not the speaker.

PP3SG.description: A relative pointer to someone else but not the speaker or the addressee.

PP3DU.description: A relative pointer to two people different from the speaker or the addressee.

PP3TRI.description: A relative pointer to three people different from the speaker or the addressee.

PP3PLU.description: A relative pointer to more people than finite count that don t include speaker or addresse.

DEFINITENESS.description: Whether an entity is considered definite or indefinite.

PERSONAL DEICTIC.description: Reference to a person or personified object in relation with the real or imaginary speaker.

PP2EXPLU.description: speaker but not addressee plus more people than discrete count

PP1EXCPLU.description: Speaker and a number of people above discrete count but not the adressee.

PP1EXCDU.description: The speaker and someone else but not the addressee

PP1PLU.description: the speaker, the addressee and more people than discrete count

existing.description: says that something exists, be plays that role in english

ABSTRACT PROPERTY.description: Any reference to an abstract property

event wildcard.description: can replace any event in questions or implicit references

OBLIQUE ROLE GOAL.description: I want the key TO open the door

OBLIQUE ROLE ORIGIN.description: FROM in I am coming from the village

OBLIQUE ROLE DESTINATION.description: as in giving something TO someone

liking.description: as in I like sweet fruits

SPATIAL DEICTIC.description: A spatial pointer relative to the real or imaginary speaker.

INTENSIFIER.description: as really in I really need this

OPEN CONVERSATION.description: in English: you know what, guess what, so, listen...

EXPRESS BELIEF (EPISTEMIC).description: English should in the train should arrive at 5pm

GIVE ADVICE (ADVISORY).description: English should in you should come with me

OBLIQUE ROLE MEDIUM.description: The medium on which an action is perfomed, as ON a notebook.

ZOOM IN.description: in time or space, as in the house, in her bedroom or on Tuesday between 2 and 4 pm

OBLIQUE ROLE TRANSFORMATION.description: as into in shredding it into pieces

pieces.description: as in shredding it into pieces

POSITION IN SEQUENCE.description: for example position 1 is first in English.

POINTER TO X.description: within a sentence, that, which, those etc

PRESENT X.description: here is X, this is X
